ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed an understanding of metric analysis of music and got exposed to many different styles of world music.
Understanding music from a rythmic (as opposed to tonal) perspective
Learned about the different aspects of meter and rhythm and how they can impact the effect music has on the listener

Professor Cohns Music 216 gives students a new, rigorous perspective about the metric structure embedded in music. Students are taught to analyze the rhythm and meter of pieces from a wide range of musical styles and world cultures (including many songs of our own selection). Throughout the semester, students make class presentations and write about their findings. If you take this class, you will finish the semester with an entirely new, incredibly useful toolbox and approach to music analysis!
Analysis of meter, phrase structure, stress patterns, etc.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think the long 75 minute lectures made it a little hard to stay engaged throughout the whole class, and I much preferred when we had exercises (like transcription) intermittently during class.
Was challenging as a beginner but helpful in introducing me to more music from all over the world and across genres!
I think there could be clearer guidelines for grading/feedback in the class

The great strength of this course is Professor Cohn, whose research is the direct basis of the course. Music 216 allows students to directly engage with material on the cutting edge of an academic field as taught by the scholar who helped invent it!

Course content is very much intuition based. Either very easy to understand and almost obvious or takes a lot of time to be able to train yourself to hear what he is talking about. A set of readings that include audio examples might be helpful.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: sure, it was a great exercise in thinking of music outside of melody and harmonics
Enjoyable class. Learned about an often less focused on topic in music

Definitely; I would especially recommend this course to any student interested in expanding their tools for analyzing music, broadening their perspective about music theory, and deepening their understanding of the connections between math and music. Professor Cohn gives students so much freedom to choose works to analyze; rather than being bound by a few already-extensively-studied pieces, we are free to choose our own path and come to our own discoveries. The class is well organized and expertly taught in a small seminar format, allowing extensive individual feedback and encouragement.
I think so. A good foundational course, but for people who already have a sophisticated sense of rhythm, it may not provide as much.
